data.title: How Much Does It Cost To Install A Mini Split AC System In 2024?
data.meta_description: Considering installing a mini split AC system? Learn more about the cost of installing a mini-split system in this comprehensive guide.
data.text:

Mini-split AC installation costs an average of $4,500 for a standard system, or between $1,200 and $16,400 for a range of sizes, efficiency ratings and brands. As the happy medium between central air and window units, mini-split AC systems provide zoned cooling without the headache of installing ductwork. Let’s take a look at the cost of a mini split AC and how it keeps your home cool and comfy all summer long.

Key Takeaways

Mini-split AC installation costs an average of $4,500 for a standard system, or between $1,200 and $16,400 for a range of sizes, efficiency ratings and brands.

Mini-split AC unit installation cost varies by type, size and number of HVAC zones.

Additional costs associated with mini-split AC unit installation include upgrades, permits, the removal of your existing AC unit and operating costs.

AVERAGE MINI SPLIT AC INSTALLATION COST

Mini Split AC Unit Installation Cost by Type

The clever design of a mini-split AC system combines an outdoor compressor with multiple evaporators, or “heads” to push cool air into individual rooms. The cost of a mini-split, therefore, really comes down to the cost of the AC compressor and the number and type of heads throughout your home.

Wall-Mounted

Wall-mounted mini-split heads are the most common and budget-friendly varieties. They typically sit at the top of the wall and link to an outdoor compressor. Wall mounts cost between $1,200 and $4,300 for a single-zoned system.

Floor-Mounted

For between $1,300 and $3,700, homeowners can install a floor-mounted mini-split AC. These heads sit closer to the floor but still on the lower part of the wall. They are often designed to supplement other heating and cooling methods and to accommodate tall windows in older homes.

Ceiling Cassette

Mimicking the look of built-in air ducts, recessed mini splits set within a ceiling cassette is a stylish option for cooling or heating a home. Ceiling cassette mini-splits cost between $2,000 and $6,000 for a standard single system.

Ceiling-Mounted

Ceiling-mounted mini-split heads combine the perks of a ceiling cassette and a standard wall mount. Attached to the ceiling, these designs cost an average of $2,400 to $5,500 each. Not only are ceiling-mounted systems out of sight, but they also typically have the best rating for airflow throughout a space.

Single-Zone

A single mini-split zone costs between $2,000 and $7,800 to install, including the outside compressor. Once you have the initial system in place, though, it costs less to add new heads and zones to the existing system.

Multi-Zone

Beyond the initial single-zone setup, add between $700 and $2,300 for additional zones in your house. While most compressors can handle multiple heads, very large systems leap in price when you add an outdoor compressor unit. Overall, a multi-zone system can cost upwards of $16,400 but ranges from $2,700 to $14,000 on average.

Mini Split AC Unit Installation Cost by Size

The first step to choosing the right mini-split setup for you is to figure out the best size AC for your home. Air conditioners measure their capacity in BTUs or British thermal units. This number measures how much an AC can cool the air in one hour. On average, you’ll need between 20 and 60 BTUs per square foot of your home.

Manufacturers also measure capacity in tons, which refers to BTUs as well. A standard 1,200-square-foot home will require about a two-ton mini-split system—or about 24,000 BTUs—which costs between $1,100 and $5,200.

Mini Split AC Unit Installation Cost by Number of HVAC Zones

A mini-split AC can separate your home into separate cooling zones. Not only does this cut down on your carbon footprint—and your utility bill—but it allows everyone in your house to set the thermostat to their comfort level. As mentioned earlier, the initial setup for a single-zone mini-split is $2,400 to $5,500. Add another $700 to $2,300 for each additional head depending on its design.

Efficiency Rating

Mini-split AC costs rise with its efficiency rating, but you’ll save in the long run by increasing your home energy efficiency overall. An air conditioner has a SEER rating, or seasonal energy efficiency ratio, to note its energy usage. Homeowners who live in particularly hot climates can save energy with high SEER ratings since their unit runs more frequently. Keep in mind that the minimum SEER rating for ACs in the US is 14 as of 2023, according to the Energy Information Administration.

Location in the Home

The placement of the mini split slightly affects your bottom line as well. Units that cool large open floor plans will need more power than those cooling a small bedroom. Higher floors also typically require more energy to cool than lower ones. Chat with your AC contractor to determine the most cost-effective way to place the mini-split heads.

Additional Costs Associated With Mini Split AC Unit Installation

There are a host of ways to customize your mini-split AC setup and some costs that can sneak up in the process. Here are a few additional things to consider.

Upgrades

Enhance both the efficiency and appearance of your mini-split with a few upgrades. Installing a new thermostat costs between $80 and $425, though keep in mind that each mini-split head often comes with a thermostat. Add a wireless controller to change your mini-split from across the room for $50 to $300 as well.

Similar upgrades include electrical and structural updates. The price to replace an electrical panel ranges from $400 to $800. Also, a specialized bracket for your unit adds between $40 and $100.

Permits

Installing a mini-split AC will occasionally require a building permit, particularly if you’re making structural changes to your home. Add between $250 and $400 for the permit depending on local laws.

Removal of Existing AC Unit

If your contractor doesn’t include removal in their price, add between $50 and $200 for the price of removing your old unit. Window units are the easiest to remove and properly dispose of while removing old compressors can cost far more.

Operating Costs

Determining the exact operating cost of your AC can be tricky, but mini-split systems tend to cost less than many other designs overall. The perk of zoned cooling means that you aren’t wasting power and money on areas not in use.

DIY Mini Split AC Unit Installation vs. Hiring a Professional for

Installing a mini-split AC is not a DIY project in most cases. Not only would you be working with complex electrical wiring, but you would also need to cut a hole in your wall or ceiling to install the AC head. Consequently, it’s not recommended to take on this job without the proper skills and training. Even experienced DIYers with an electrical background should have a certified inspector take a look at their installation work to prevent any safety concerns.

Tips for Saving on Mini Split AC Unit Installation Costs

Since the DIY route won’t necessarily save you money, consider a few other ways to keep your mini-split price low.

Hire an HVAC contractor off-season to avoid peak rates.

Begin with a single-zoned system and increase zones if or when necessary.

Opt for wall-mounted mini-split heads.

Speak with at least three HVAC pros to compare estimates.

Consider a home energy audit before your installation to enhance your home’s efficiency.

Invest in a mini-split with a high SEER rating to lower operating costs.

Tips for Hiring a Professional Mini Split AC Unit Installer

Before meeting with a prospective pro, get ready with a list of questions to ask your HVAC tech. Your contractor should be trained, certified and insured. They should be able to provide customer testimonials and examples of similar projects they’ve worked on in the past. Additionally, be sure to request:

A guaranteed estimate for the job

The payment terms throughout the project

A predicted timeline for the work

References from past clients or coworkers

If there are changes to the estimate, determine how this will be communicated

To arrive at the average costs in this article, we surveyed eight local and national cost databases. All averaged figures were correct at the time of publication and may be subject to change.

Frequently Asked Questions (FAQs)

What are the disadvantages of a mini-split system?

The downsides to a mini-split AC unit are the upfront costs and relatively complicated installation. Mini-split ACs cool individual rooms, which is great for efficiency but not as ideal if you’re trying to cool an entire home regularly. Each mini-split head also requires complex maintenance throughout the year, so it’s best to have an HVAC pro on hand to ensure it’s running smoothly.

How many hours does it take to install a mini-split?

Installing a mini-split AC unit will cost between four and six hours depending on the size of the system. Contractors will need to connect an outdoor compressor to one or more evaporator heads throughout your home. The time frame lengthens up to eight hours when contractors need to make changes to your electrical panels or install recessed ceiling cassettes.

How many rooms can a mini-split cool?

An individual mini-split head cools one room, but a system with multiple zones can easily cool a whole house. The number of rooms depends on the capacity of the city, the placement of the heads and your local climate. In most cases, a single mini-split compressor can handle up to eight heads.
